prompts:
you're workingon beads issue FIN-97047. here was the original prompt: "ok, go through all the markdown files in my obsidian vaults, located in folderx I to X, recursively, and use regex       
  search or grep to find all block latex equations, and then run a team of 25 subagents with haiku-4.5 running in          
  parallel to review and fix any issues with them. each agent should only handle 1 document's latex equations at a         
  time to prevent overloading, and when 1 is done, spin up another 1 to take its place. look out for issues with           
  spacing and \text{} and \mathrm{} and \circ and \bullet, and other formatting issues like spaces between letters of      
  a word, or issues with superscripts or subscripts, or other issues, and resolve them. do this manually, since this       
  requires subagents to intelligently understand the equation and what is wrong with it in that specific context. do       
  not have the agent blindly make edits using blanket scripts over equations it has never seen before. use targetted       
  edits to fix specific formatting issues. create a new bead issue and provide all the instructions needed for the         
  subagents, and  make the subagents update the bead issues with documents it has completed already, and also keep a       
  log document of the documents processed and the specific edits made to incorrect latex equations. you can create a       
  robust script for the agents to run to quickly capture all the latex equations in a given document. teach the agents     
  how to use it. additional resources available in the @styleguide/ folder but you only need to pay attention to the       
  parts regarding latex equation formatting. ultrathink       ok, update the beads issue and note the completed files. then spin up the next round of 25 subagents, and monitor        
  the progress every 10 minutes or so. im noticing that a lot of the subagents run into the issue where it says            
  Context low · Run /compact to compact & continue. should this be happening if they are only reviewing the latex          
  equations in a document and not the entire document? whats going on here that is causing the context windows of the      
  agents to be eaten up so quickly. are they reviewing all the latex equations in their documents, or is their context     
  window filled up before they can do so? to preserve your own context window, you dont have to review the outputs of      
  the agents, just keep the beads issues updated if the subagents arent doing so themselves, and spin up new               
  sibagents whenever one agent is complete. remember to use haiku-4.5 for the subagents.  " keep working on it. manage your own context window wisely
